Although gun lovers claim the recent surge in sales across the country is due to a growing fear that the Obama Administration is secretly planning an all-out assault on Americans' Constitutionally-guaranteed right to bear arms, workers in the sex industry state there is another reason for the increase: Sexual dysfunction.
 
 Employees of the Busty Bunny Brothel, which has two locations outside of Las Vegas and one near downtown Reno, have been compiling data for a while now, and have finally come out with the results of their anecdotal study ... and their findings are startling.
 
 The madam at "The Bunny" as original establishment is called, said the women - who call themselves "sexologists" - have been noticing a fairly recent phenomenon: The men who come into the facilities toting guns have a much higher rate of erectile dysfunction than men who are not armed. Tania "Tits" Thompson, the owner of the string of brothels that is used by over 3,000 men per week, said that she has been reluctant to go public with the findings out of fear of a loss of business. 
 New Study Links Guns, Sexual Dysfunction | Cleveland Leader
 
 I knew it!

...Dr. Joyce Brothers claims that gun ownership is a symptom of sexual dysfunction.
The places I see this supposed quote by Dr. Brothers are invariably pro-gun. Do you know where the quote originates?
 
 Could it be this response to a letter:
 
 Thursday, February 26, 2004
 
 Owning guns helps erase feelings of inferiority
 
 By DR. JOYCE BROTHERS
 SYNDICATED COLUMNIST
 
 DEAR DR. BROTHERS: My husband and I live in a gated community that could hardly be safer. This choice of a place to live was mine, incidentally, not his. We both work at jobs in a nearby city, and we're not threatened in any unusual way. Our offices are pleasant and in good areas. What I'm trying to figure out is why my husband needs so many guns. He's an old Army guy, but none of his friends seems to have this particular fascination with guns, so I don't think that explains it. I bring this up now because he told me recently that he found two more he's going to buy from yet another gun dealer. They're not cheap, and we could use that money to clean up some of our bills. -- E.C.
 
 DEAR E.C.: Gun ownership is extremely important to some people, and often they're not aware of why. To most, the gun means added power, something that erases all feelings of inferiority, weakness, vulnerability and impotence. It's not irrelevant that guns, in themselves, are so frequently linked to sexuality and the male sex organ. Think of the many slang terms common to both sex and guns, and the relationship becomes obvious. Guns have been accurately called "the great equalizer."
 Owning guns helps erase feelings of inferiority

 Despite all of the claims that have been made I've seen no sufficient evidence to suggest that people choose to own guns because of impotence and sexual dysfunction. I've seen evidence that they choose to own a gun for all manner of reasons such as: increased crime rates, fewer police officers, slower police response times, danger while traveling, attack by wild animals, sport, hunting, collecting, and because it's an individual constitutional right and needs to justification for it to be exercised in the first place.
 
 Of course this could raise an interesting question. If people choose to own guns because they suffer sexual dysfunction, are gun control advocates homophobic and afraid of sex? If guns represent compensation then surely those who seek to deprive people of guns have an overwhelming fear of the concept of sexual vitality.
 
 But sexual dysfunction doesn't seem to be on the list of reasons for why people choose to become a gun owner. And this fact is only hammered home when you consider how many micro guns are owned. If people really were compensating for their own sexual inadequacy by owning a gun then one of these North American Arms mini-revolvers chambered for the .22 Short surely wouldn't be the way to go about doing it. Nobody would own anything less than the biggest guns they could get. There would be a lot more Barrett rifles and .500 Magnum revolvers in circulation than there are right now if it's all about sexual compensation.
 
 And now we come to the question round and the supporters of Dr. Joyce Brothers get to start justifying their position that they're trying to establish.
 
 Even if people with sexual dysfunction do choose to own guns, what exactly does that have to do with anything? Gun ownership is a constitutional right, any adult who isn't clinically insane or a felon is free to exercise this right anytime they want without need to justify their decision to anyone other than themselves and their saving accounts.
 
 Of course then we come to Brady's newest position of foolishness. According to Brady any regular person who chooses to own a gun is simply compensation for sexual dysfunction, but when the person in question is a soldier or a police officer (even one who is retired and no longer able to contribute to society like they originally could) then they suffer absolutely no sexual dysfunction and their status of being armed is because they need to be armed to address whatever threat might arise. Threats that specifically target the police exclusively and leave everyone else alone.
 
 Of course that brings about another interesting question. If only the police need guns because only the police ever face the risk of danger from day to day, why are there between 10,000 and 15,000 homicides committed each year with a gun, but only a minute number of those thousands are police officers? Were all of the non-police murder victims simply caught in the crossfire and nothing more than casualties of an attempt to murder a police officer?

Of course this could raise an interesting question. If people choose to own guns because they suffer sexual dysfunction, are gun control advocates homophobic and afraid of sex? If guns represent compensation then surely those who seek to deprive people of guns have an overwhelming fear of the concept of sexual vitality.
Either that or they are hung and hard on demand which would be the actual converse you wish to overlook.

U.S. certifying the long standing tradition and individual right to keep and bear arms and the common law right of CITIZEN ARREST pretty well shows who the LIARS are and why they keep right on losing. That is not even metioning {I]Heller nor McDonald[/I]. When your sheep mind joins the real world it will be too late. You antipodeans gave up any claim to rights you may have had and got raped out of them by incidents like the Bryant episode which you evidently know nothing about. 
 
 The only other thing that is evident, even money says your mother continually says, "baaaaaaa". :)

 
 ****Correction: that should be U.S v. Staples. Pardon for the reverse parties.

Well Winston Smith it seems as though you're just another in a long line of people who have no debating skills and lacks the simple ability to engage in honest discussion. Here we've shown our intelligence and exercised our ability to engage in honest and civil debate, showing the fallacy of the belief that gun ownership is a symptom of sexual dysfunction, disproving Galileo and his citing of prostitutes as source material. We've systematically proven the fallacy of this argument, and what do you have to offer in response? Crude sexual references designed to infuriate others.
 
 Some want to believe that the only reason anybody would own a gun is to compensate for their shortcomings in bed. However based on your recent posts I believe that it's you who's compensating, resorting to crude sexual references and trolling tactics in an attempt to hide the fact that you couldn't engage in an honest debate if your life depended on it. Small minds such as yours go for the quick and easy, a position that can easily be decimated in a matter of minutes by someone with the ability to think.
 
 The fact of the matter is that we're superior to you simply because we're capable of putting far more thought and effort into our works then you would ever consider doing for your own. So instead you try and degrade the discussion into trolling and flaming and rhetoric in hopes of the point being forgotten because you can't address it. You try and insult us in hopes we'll insult you back and get far off topic from what the thread started out as. It's a fairly standard liberal tactic designed to shut down honest debate. The tactic got a lot of use during the health care reform debates, with liberal supporters simply chanting "health care now!" and using it as the entirety of their argumentative position. No reasoning for why the bill should we allowed to be signed into law, no covering important points and criticism, just quick soundbyte statements that're devoid of substance and reasonability.
 
 And then we come to your constantly repeated term of "gun crazies" that you seem to readily apply to anyone who doesn't believe in further gun control.
 
 Despite what you and others may want to believe to the contrary gun ownership is recognized as a constitutional right and protected just like any other right in the constitution. There's nothing you can do to change that fact. So when you slam gun owners you're basically attacking people who believe in and support the constitution itself and all it stands for and protects.
 
 Let's look at your tactic and slandering people as "gun crazies" for a minute. Since you're attacking those who support the constitution then perhaps you'd care to extend the scope of your attack to people who might qualify as "book crazies" or "privacy nuts" or "trial by jury fanatics" just to name a few other constitutional points?
 
 I don't know what part of the world you may hark from, but the constitution still exists in America. All of its protections and recognized rights are equal to each other, all subject to the same respect and protection against infringement. Nobody has the authority to play pick and choose. Nobody is allowed to recognize only certain rights that they agree with and pretending that all others don't exist. It's an all or nothing package deal with no inbetween.

 Brady is right in looking for the cause behind the madness: obsession with owning guns. It is a disease for sure and of the dangerous kind.

Brady is right in looking for the cause behind the madness: obsession with owning guns. It is a disease for sure and of the dangerous kind.

 
 Obsession with owning guns is a cause of madness? Exactly how do you arrive at that conclusion? How do you classify it as a disease? Do you extend that derogatory standard to other items within the constitution that people have a desire to take part in?
 
 Perhaps you'd care to slander those that read books? Maybe mock those who insist on having an attorney present during questioning? Offer up a few derogatory remarks regarding those who value privacy against government intrusion? Perhaps you would care to explain the madness of your government for declaring that imitation firearms must be licensed and locked up exactly like their real world functioning counterparts? I'd love to hear somebody actually come out in favor of such a foolish standard.
 
 Australia possesses no true constitution designed to protect the people and restrict the power of government. If your government chooses to do something you have very little legal recourse at your disposal. Perhaps that's why you choose to slander those of us who are fortunate enough to live in America and enjoy true measures of freedom. You're unable to know what it's like to know the government is restricted in its authority over the people and you can't stand that.
 
 Gun ownership is not a symptom of madness. However rampant distrust of your fellow citizens certainly does qualify. If you honestly believe your own neighbors can't be trusted unless they've been forcibly disarmed by government mandate then that doesn't sound like a very healthy way of life.
